security_audit.summary: Legitimate environment configuration management skill. Provides filesystem access to .env files and environment variable reading for configuration purposes. All capabilities align with stated purpose. Includes encryption utilities and security best practices documentation.

low_findings.title: Filesystem access for .env files
low_findings.description: The skill reads and writes .env files for configuration management. This is necessary for the stated purpose of environment configuration but represents filesystem access. Code at scripts/env_helper.py:46 reads files with `open(path, 'r')` for parsing environment files. No access outside project directory.

low_findings.title: Environment variable reading
low_findings.description: The skill uses os.getenv() to read environment variables for configuration. This is standard for configuration management. No bulk collection of system environment variables. Limited to application-specific vars like APP_NAME, DATABASE_URL, API keys.

content.user_title: Configure environments and manage secrets securely
content.value_statement: Python projects need secure environment configuration to prevent credential leaks and support multiple deployment environments. This skill provides patterns and utilities for managing .env files, encrypting secrets, and implementing configuration best practices with UV.
actual_capabilities: Parse and validate .env files for environment configuration
Encrypt and decrypt secrets files using Fernet encryption
Compare environment configurations across development and production
Generate .env templates with sensitive values masked
Validate required environment variables on application startup
Support multi-environment setups with dev, staging, and production configs
limitations: Does not integrate with cloud secret managers like AWS Secrets Manager
Requires manual deployment of encrypted secrets to production
Does not provide runtime secret rotation without application restart

use_cases.title: Set up secure configuration
use_cases.description: Configure new Python projects with environment variables, .env files, and secrets encryption from project start.

use_cases.title: Manage multi-environment configs
use_cases.description: Maintain separate configurations for development, staging, and production with validation and security checks.

use_cases.title: Prevent credential leaks
use_cases.description: Implement configuration patterns that prevent API keys and passwords from entering version control.

prompt_templates.title: New project setup
prompt_templates.scenario: Initialize Python project with environment config
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up a new Python project with UV, create .env.template with APP_NAME, APP_ENV, DATABASE_URL, ANTHROPIC_API_KEY variables, and add appropriate entries to .gitignore for secrets protection.

prompt_templates.title: Validate configuration
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my .env file and check for missing required variables, placeholder values like 'xxx' or 'changeme', and short passwords or secrets under 12 characters. Report any security issues found.

prompt_templates.title: Encrypt secrets
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an encrypted version of my secrets.json file using the env_helper.py encryption utilities. Show me how to decrypt it at runtime in my application.

prompt_templates.title: Compare environments
prompt_templates.prompt: Compare my .env.development and .env.production files to identify all differences. Show which variables are only in each file and which have different values between environments.

output_examples.input: Set up environment configuration for my new Python API project
output: ‚úì Create .env.template with common variables (APP_NAME, DATABASE_URL, API keys)
‚úì Generate encryption utilities for sensitive data
‚úì Provide validation of required variables on startup

best_practices: Never commit .env files with real secrets to version control
Use different encryption keys for each environment
Validate all required configuration variables at application startup
anti_patterns: Hardcoding API keys or passwords directly in source code
Using placeholder values like 'xxx' or 'changeme' in production
Sharing the same .env file across development and production environments

faq.question: Which Python versions are supported?
faq.answer: Python 3.10 and newer. UV requires Python 3.8+ but this skill targets modern Python projects.

faq.question: What secrets can this skill encrypt?
faq.answer: Any JSON file containing sensitive data like API keys, database credentials, and tokens using Fernet symmetric encryption.

faq.question: How do I integrate with existing code?
faq.answer: Import the Config class from your config module and use property access like config.anthropic_api_key for all environment variables.

faq.question: Is my configuration data sent anywhere?
faq.answer: No. All processing happens locally. The skill only reads your .env files and environment variables on your machine.

faq.question: Why are my environment variables not loading?
faq.answer: Check that .env file exists in your project root, is readable, and uses KEY=value format without spaces around the equals sign.

faq.question: How does this compare to python-dotenv alone?
faq.answer: This skill provides additional patterns for validation, encryption, multi-environment support, and security auditing beyond basic .env loading.
